TopicTitle: Ask the Mods questions about the Forums!

Articles.Content:
> 
> 
> 4 hours ago, Random-E said:
> 
> 
> i've noticed that there's a lot of forums threads that're missing, especially when i go old mod hunting.
> 

Probably got deleted.

> 
> 
> 23 hours ago, Random-E said:
> 
> 
> i've noticed that there's a lot of forums threads that're missing, especially when i go old mod hunting.
> 

Hard to say without knowing something more specific.  Are you saying that you have a bookmark that used to work, and now when you get there it says "no such thread"?  Or are you just typing stuff in the search box and not finding it?

If it's the latter, that doesn't necessarily mean that the thread is "missing"-- it could just be that you don't have the keywords quite right.  Also, my observation has been that the forum's "search" function isn't super robust and it can often be difficult to find what one is looking for.

> 
> 
> 19 hours ago, Admiral Fluffy said:
> 
> 
> Probably got deleted.
> 

This seems pretty unlikely to me.  Note that the *<u>author</u>* of a thread doesn't have the ability to delete it.  The only people who can remove threads are *<u>moderators</u>*, and we rarely do that, and basically never to mod threads (generally this only happens to spammer threads, or really toxic threads that were on forbidden topics from the get-go, that sort of thing).

There have been a (very) few cases where some modder got unhappy for whatever reason and left the forum, and chose to make their threads difficult to locate afterwards (e.g. editing the subject and <abbr title="1. Original Post(er). The first post in a thread, or the person who posted it. 2. Overpowered. A part or mechanic that upsets game balance by being too powerful."><abbr title="1. Original Post(er). The first post in a thread, or the person who posted it. 2. Overpowered. A part or mechanic that upsets game balance by being too powerful.">OP</abbr></abbr> of their thread to just be a dash or something).  That's pretty rare, though-- there haven't been many cases of that.  (And no, we're not going to discuss specifics about who did that to which mods, out of respect for people's privacy; nor would it be appropriate to speculate on motives or anything else.  So please don't ask.)

> 
> 
> 19 hours ago, Admiral Fluffy said:
> 
> 
> Probably got deleted.
> 

We have also had a number of forum crashes over the years. And unfortunately, that will sometimes wipe out a forum post or two.

> 
> 
> Just now, Snark said:
> 
> 
> This seems pretty unlikely to me.  Note that the *<u>author</u>* of a thread doesn't have the ability to delete it.  The only people who can remove threads are *<u>moderators</u>*, and we rarely do that, and basically never to mod threads (generally this only happens to spammer threads, or really toxic threads that were on forbidden topics from the get-go, that sort of thing).
> 

I meant deleted by the forum software itself.

What i think [@Random-E](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/219578-random-e/) is saying that a thread is linked, but when you click on it, it says 'That thread is not available' or something like that.

> 
> 
> 9 minutes ago, Admiral Fluffy said:
> 
> 
> What i think [@Random-E](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/219578-random-e/) is saying that a thread is linked, but when you click on it, it says 'That thread is not available' or something like that.
> 

Well, that's not a bad *<u>guess</u>*, but we don't actually know without clarification, thus my question.  ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif ":)")  And it would be impossible to deal with any sort of generality like that-- would need to see an actual example.

One of the forum software upgrades changed the URL format and renumbered the threads. Often you can still find them with a web search or via <abbr title="Comprehensive Kerbal Archive Network (a KSP mod manager)"><abbr title="Comprehensive Kerbal Archive Network (a KSP mod manager)">CKAN</abbr></abbr>. For example this (former) thread:

- [http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/54954](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/54954)

is now here:

- [https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/50296-112-deadly-reentry-v790-the-barbie-edition-aug-5th-2021/](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/50296-112-deadly-reentry-v790-the-barbie-edition-aug-5th-2021/)

Hey [@Snark](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/125662-snark/), do you have one of these yet?

[@Dman979](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/123837-dman979/) I gotta ask, is it Dee-Man or Da-Man? The latter being with slightly more enthusiasm and finger-gunning ![;)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_wink.gif ";)")

Hi moderators, I'm commenting here because there's no "report" option on [https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/guidelines/](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/guidelines/) ...

> 
> 
> Quote
> 
> 
> 5. Miscellaneous
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 5.1 Add-ons
> 
> 
> 
> 
> A more detailed set of rules regarding add-ons and add-on licensing can be found **here** and must be followed at all times.
> 

The text "here" is a link to [https://www.kerbalspaceprogram.com/add-on-posting-rules/](https://www.kerbalspaceprogram.com/add-on-posting-rules/) , which is a 404 broken link. So the add-on posting rules currently aren't very easy to find.

We’ll get this straightened out.

So... What subforums will be added in early 2023? I mean, if we still use this forum instead of starting a new one? 

I can think of a new Add-on subforum dedicated for KSP2, because KSP1 mods will possibly malfunction, if not useless, in KSP2. I think the devs has changed the file structure completely.

And a KSP2 Technical support subforum? It seems to me that most other subforums can work well even when the two games are mixed together.
